pageText.defaultText: Introduction

Congratulations on acquiring your new engine. Please take the time to get well acquainted with your motor by reading this handbook. The more you know and understand about your motor, the greater the safety and pleasure you will derive from usage. For more information on IVLabs and its products visit the following website:
https://discord.gg/w24XKcE

Engine exhaust, some of its constituents, and certain engine fluids contain or emit chemicals known to the State of California to cause cancer and birth defects or other reproductive harm. In addition, certain fluids contained in radiator and certain products of component wear contain or emit chemicals known to the State of California to cause cancer and birth defects or other reproductive harm.
Safety Warnings

Before attempting any self-repairs on your motor, be sure to remove all loose articles of clothing as well as ensuring that the engine is not running, and cool to the touch.
IVLabs does not take responsibilty for any injuries or damages incurred by attempting to repair one's engine without the proper tools or experience.

Avoid all electrical systems, or ensure that the battery terminals have been properly disconnected before attempting to repair or modify any electrical systems.
Dispose of used motor oil, intake/AC/oil filters, radiator coolant or batteries appropriately, as many of these products are harmful to the environment if not properly recycled/disposed of.
Operation

Check that your vehicle is fully charged, and has enough fuel to make a full trip before starting engine. If the vehicle has enough fuel and power, open the vehicle panel (Default key: U) and click the ENGINE button to the right once to engage the engine, then click and hold until you hear the engine fully start.

Once the engine has started, give it some time to warm up to operating temperature, otherwise you risk damaging vital components or wearing out the block.
Afterwards, put the engine into gear (Default keys: R - Upshift, F - Downshift) and slowly accelerate. (Default keys: R-Shift+W)
Should harder acceleration or higher speed be required, release the MOD key (R-Shift) to increase throttle.
Engine Longevity

In order to maintain engine longevity, follow these tips to get the most lifetime out of your engines.

- Maintain an engine speed below its listed maximum safe RPM, by lowering throttle or upshifting in a standard transmission.

- Allow the engine to warm up in colder biomes, and allow the engine to remain cool in warmer biomes.

- Consider shifting into neutral and shutting off the engine at long stoplights, saving fuel as well.

- Change oil and oil filters at regular intervals.
(this one isn't possible in MTS yet)

- Lock your vehicle to prevent vandals from opening the hood and causing unwanted damage/theft.
Insolvo

The Insolvo engine line is a budgetary option meant for people who prefer gas mileage and reliabiltiy to comfort.
These engines are simple, easy to repair and are fairly light, the perfect combination for any economic vehicles.
However, everything in life comes at a costâ€” power.
While cheap and fuel efficient, these engines are not the best choice for performance vehicles.

Due to their simplicity, Insolvo engines do not require an Engine Control Unit, nor do they use fuel injection systems, which reduces the amount of effort required when working on an Insolvo.
Many of these engines come in Inline, Boxer or Vee configurations, as well as two or four stroke.
Median

The Median engine line is the standard option, offering a balanced combination of fuel efficiency, power and quiet exhaust.
Fuel injection allows these engines to make the best use of consumed fuel, while the reverse flow exhaust minimizes the total noise and exhaust fumes created as a byproduct. While not cheap, these engines are easy to come by and are available in Inline or Vee configurations.

Maintenance, while not as easy as working on an Insolvo, is still relatively simple as these engines use a simpler Engine Control Unit as well as being built into an Alumi-Starâ„¢ alloy block, making self-servicing fairly simple for the most part as long as the oil and oil filter are changed on a regular basis.
Performante

The Performante engine line is a premium option for those who only wish for more power to the wheels, while making as much noise as possible.
Advanced fuel injection systems and a top-of-the-line Engine Control Unit allows for only the highest of speeds achievable by man.
Quite expensive, but available in Inline and Vee configurations.

Due to their extreme complexity, self-service is not advisable at risk of injury, damage or loss of power, particularly due to the rarity of Performante engine parts.
Additionally, IVLabs does not take responsibility for collisions or damage caused by street racing or launches, nor will such incidents be compensated by warranty should investigation lead to the cause being user error rather than a part defect.
Torqueline

The Torqueline engine line is a heavy-built option for larger vehicles such as semi-trucks, busses, military vehicles or other heavy transport vehicles.
Built with a multi-port mechanical fuel injection system and a forged steel engine block, maintenance is only limited by size of the engine combined with cab access.

Expensive up-front price but pays for itself in the long run due to reliability. Torqueline engines only come in Vee configurations*,  and Light Duty / Heavy Duty variants with different tuning and gearbox ratios.
Can also come equipped with a turbo-spool system for additional power, with anywhere from one to four turbochargers installed for additional power and fuel economy.
*Not canon, subject to change with upcoming pack updates

Prices subject to change due to exchange rates, buyer history or current supply
Repair Services

Self-service of IVLabs motors is not advised unless you have the proper tools and experience. However, there are IVLabs Approved service shops available to service your engine for a small cost, while temporarily lending you a rental vehicle during servicing.
IVLabs does not take responsibility for damage or failures caused by self-serviced engines, or servicing done by an unapproved service shop.
